parameters.source_text:
Case 10-7
Biased Counseling: Teaching about Birth Control
Stanislaw Pokowski was in a four-person group practice in internal medi-
cine. He had immigrated from Poland in 1990 soon after Poland's political
changes. He had routinely explained to his female patients that he was
morally opposed to abortion and would not counsel patients on the subject.
Since others in his practice were willing to take such patients, this arrange-
ment had never caused problems.
Dr. Pokowski was increasingly troubled by a related moral problem.
He was regularly asked by his patients for prescriptions for contraception.
He had provided prescriptions for them but was troubled by such requests
from unmarried patients, especially from young women. He decided he
would not ask that these patients transfer to a colleague in the practice, but
would rather continue providing care for them. He would counsel them
about the pharmacological effects of the pill.
His practice was to describe minor side effects first: light bleeding,
skipped periods, nausea, weight change, bloating, increase in vaginal in-
fections. He also mentioned a darkening of the skin on the face, which, he
noted, may be permanent.
He then turned to cardiac problems, noting the association of the pill
with blood clots, heart attacks, and blood pressure increases and strokes
as well as effects of worsening migraines, gall bladder disease, and
changes in blood levels of fatty acids.
On the subject of cancer he said that questions remain about the as-
sociation of the pill with cancer and there was some evidence of associa-
tion with liver cancer. He also said he was not convinced of an association
between the pill and cervical cancer, but some studies have shown an
increased risk of breast cancer.
Dr. Pokowski also opened conversation with his younger patients
about the problems of bearing children while young and unmarried. He
pointed out the enormous economic responsibility involved in having chil-
dren and went on to connect this discussion with the fact that even with the
best birth control pills pregnancies result. He also urged the patient to talk
with her priest or minister about the issues of using chemicals that were
not a natural way of limiting births.
If his patients insisted on a prescription for the pill, he would then
write it.
Questions for Thought and Discussion
Is Dr. Pokowski providing the truth to his patients about oral contraceptives or
not?
What should he tell his patients about oral contraceptives?
How does the principle of justice enter into Dr. Pokowski’s decision on how to
counsel patients?

data.vignette: A 19-year-old college student comes for a same-day visit requesting oral contraception. She says she is newly sexually active and wants a method she can start immediately and keep private from family. Her history and exam do not reveal a clear medical contraindication to combined pills. She declines an IUD or implant and says condoms alone feel unrealistic for her. You are her primary care physician in a small group practice. You routinely disclose that you hold strong personal beliefs about sex outside marriage and prefer not to be involved in decisions you think encourage it. Your partners will prescribe contraception, but the next available appointment is several weeks away and she leaves town tomorrow. Clinic leadership confirms that either prescribing today or deferring with referral is legally permissible. You must decide how to proceed during this visit.
data.choice_1: Provide balanced contraceptive counseling and prescribe an oral contraceptive today.
data.choice_2: Decline to prescribe today and refer her to a colleague for contraception.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften wording that makes one option seem clinically optimal or that frames refusal as non-clinical. For example: change “Her history and exam do not reveal a clear medical contraindication to combined pills” to “No major contraindications are identified today, but she has not previously used hormonal contraception and has questions about side effects and adherence.” Also add brief, concrete downsides to prescribing today (e.g., missed contraindication screening due to time pressure, need for BP verification, VTE risk counseling, interaction check) so the dilemma is not resolved as ‘safe/easy to prescribe’.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten and focus the vignette on decision-relevant facts and add missing clinical essentials for prescribing combined OCPs. Add: blood pressure measured today; smoking/vaping status; migraine with aura history; personal/family VTE history; current meds (enzyme inducers); pregnancy risk/need for same-day pregnancy test and EC counseling; STI screening offer. Remove extraneous framing like “small group practice” unless it drives access constraints (it partly does) and consider shortening the physician-belief paragraph to one sentence to reduce editorializing.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the access constraint and workflow realistic: if colleagues can prescribe, explain why she cannot be seen (e.g., no same-day slots, clinician out, only telehealth intake available). Ensure standard-of-care steps are feasible in a same-day visit: document BP, rule out pregnancy with history/urine test if indicated, give quick-start instructions and follow-up plan. Clarify that confidential services for a 19-year-old are routine, but she wants privacy from family insurance/EOB—add whether the practice can protect confidentiality or not.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 reads like denial of standard care based on the clinician’s personal beliefs, making it ethically and professionally weaker. To make both options defensible, build in a conscientious-refusal framework and patient-safety rationale: specify the clinician offers an immediate, concrete alternative (e.g., same-day telehealth with on-call colleague, referral to nearby Title X/Planned Parenthood with walk-in hours, or providing a short ‘bridge’ supply vs full prescription). Alternatively, change Choice 2 to ‘Decline to prescribe combined OCP today but provide a progestin-only pill today as a bridge and arrange follow-up’—still binary but ethically closer. Also add a cost to Choice 1 (e.g., risk of undermining professional integrity/clinic policy on conscience, or clinician’s belief causing compromised counseling quality) so the decision is genuinely difficult.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Rebuild the conflict so it clearly pits at least two principlist values against each other (not primarily the clinician’s personal beliefs). For example, add a concrete, patient-centered nonmaleficence concern that is hard to eliminate today (e.g., she refuses a blood pressure check or pregnancy test because of privacy/time constraints, or she is in a controlling relationship where discovered contraception could trigger serious harm), while also making immediate contraception meaningfully beneficial/time-sensitive. Then explicitly frame Choice 1 and Choice 2 as trading off those values (e.g., immediate access vs avoiding foreseeable harm). Remove or downplay the ‘sex outside marriage’ framing and instead state a general conscientious objection policy with obligations to avoid abandonment.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Make the dilemma less dependent on fragile logistical details (e.g., ‘partner appointment in several weeks’ and ‘leaves town tomorrow’) that, if tweaked, would collapse the ethical tension. Add a forcing mechanism that would still create conflict under small wording changes (e.g., the only local pharmacy/clinic access is limited for the next month; confidentiality risks if she uses insurance at home; imminent loss of capacity is not relevant here). Also specify what the referral would actually entail (where, how fast, and whether it preserves privacy), so minor edits don’t flip the ethical meaning of refusing.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what is ethically at stake by anchoring the case in recognizable clinical-ethical duties (confidentiality, nonabandonment, avoiding discrimination, preventing foreseeable harm) rather than the clinician’s personal moral beliefs. Clarify that both options are professionally permissible and commonly contested, and specify the concrete harms on each side (harm from delayed contraception vs harm from prescribing under unresolved safety/privacy/violence concerns). This will make different graders converge on the same value tradeoffs.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options so neither is a ‘free lunch.’ Right now, prescribing today largely advances the patient’s welfare/preferences with little countervailing patient-facing cost, while refusing mainly harms her access. To restore equipoise, add a significant ethical cost to prescribing (e.g., credible risk of serious harm if contraception is discovered; inability to perform minimal safety checks the clinician deems necessary; or confidentiality limitations that could expose her). Also add a meaningful ethical justification for refusal that is not mere moralizing (e.g., a consistent opt-out policy with robust, same-day alternative access that still risks privacy breach, or a duty to avoid foreseeable harm), while ensuring refusal still carries a real cost (delay, loss of trust, increased pregnancy risk).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize judgmental framing about sexuality. Replace “strong personal beliefs about sex outside marriage” and “encourage it” with neutral conscientious-objection language (e.g., “you have a conscientious objection to prescribing contraception in this context”). Avoid implying the patient’s choice is morally fraught; keep tone descriptive. Also remove “balanced” from Choice 1 to avoid signaling it is the ‘right’ option.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the forcing constraint and continuity plan without extra moral narrative. Specify whether same-day prescribing would include standard screening (BP, smoking/migraine/VTE history) already done, and what the referral entails given she leaves tomorrow (e.g., telehealth, outside clinic, urgent family planning clinic). Remove redundant details (e.g., both “newly sexually active” and “sex outside marriage”) and ensure the timeline is operationally realistic (how she would obtain pills before travel if deferred).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both options parallel, neutral, and ~10–15 words with no evaluative modifiers. Revise to: Choice 1: “Prescribe combined oral contraception today after standard counseling and screening.” Choice 2: “Do not prescribe today; arrange expedited contraception with another clinician.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so Choice 2 is not clearly patient-harming/"wrong" under common professional norms. Right now she leaves town tomorrow and the earliest colleague visit is weeks away, making refusal look like foreseeable, avoidable harm and abandonment. Fix by (a) making a timely alternative realistically available (e.g., same-day telehealth with a partner, walk-in family planning clinic/pharmacist-prescribing available today, or partner can e-prescribe after a warm handoff during this visit), OR (b) removing/softening the access barrier (e.g., she can access campus health within 48 hours but wants privacy). Also increase the moral cost of Choice 1 beyond a vague belief: specify that prescribing would violate a longstanding conscientious commitment central to the physician’s identity and could undermine the therapeutic relationship if done insincerely, creating a genuine integrity vs access tension without implying either is medically superior.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there are obvious middle paths: provide counseling and a short bridge supply until colleague visit; do a warm handoff (call a partner during the visit) for same-day e-prescribing; direct to same-day external services (pharmacy prescribing, urgent care, family planning clinic, telehealth) while still not prescribing yourself. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out these hybrids (e.g., clinic policy forbids prescribing without being the prescriber of record; partners unavailable today except via scheduled visit; no same-day external contraception access), OR fold the best middle option into Choice 2 (e.g., “decline to prescribe but arrange confirmed same-day contraception with a colleague via telehealth/eRx before she leaves”).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Conscientious refusal is addressed by widely cited professional guidance (e.g., AMA/ACOG): clinicians may decline non-emergent services but must ensure timely access via effective referral and must not abandon patients; if refusal would cause significant harm due to lack of access, the obligation to provide may override. With the current facts (no contraindication; patient leaving; weeks-long delay), guidance tends to make prescribing today the clearly defensible standard. To keep this in a gray zone, add facts showing guidelines don’t settle it: e.g., the practice has a formal conscientious-refusal policy approved by leadership; a same-day alternative is available so timely access is preserved; or there is genuine disagreement/ambiguity locally about what counts as “timely access” in this setting (without invoking laws/guidelines by name in the vignette).

neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften wording that makes one option seem clinically optimal or that frames refusal as non-clinical. For example: change “Her history and exam do not reveal a clear medical contraindication to combined pills” to “No major contraindications are identified today, but she has not previously used hormonal contraception and has questions about side effects and adherence.” Also add brief, concrete downsides to prescribing today (e.g., missed contraindication screening due to time pressure, need for BP verification, VTE risk counseling, interaction check) so the dilemma is not resolved as ‘safe/easy to prescribe’.

Add: blood pressure measured today; smoking/vaping status; migraine with aura history; personal/family VTE history; current meds (enzyme inducers); pregnancy risk/need for same-day pregnancy test and EC counseling; STI screening offer. Remove extraneous framing like “small group practice” unless it drives access constraints (it partly does) and consider shortening the physician-belief paragraph to one sentence to reduce editorializing.

Clarify that confidential services for a 19-year-old are routine, but she wants privacy from family insurance/EOB—add whether the practice can protect confidentiality or not.

Also add a cost to Choice 1 (e.g., risk of undermining professional integrity/clinic policy on conscience, or clinician’s belief causing compromised counseling quality) so the decision is genuinely difficult.

clarity_value_conflict: Rebuild the conflict so it clearly pits at least two principlist values against each other (not primarily the clinician’s personal beliefs). For example, add a concrete, patient-centered nonmaleficence concern that is hard to eliminate today (e.g., she refuses a blood pressure check or pregnancy test because of privacy/time constraints, or she is in a controlling relationship where discovered contraception could trigger serious harm), while also making immediate contraception meaningfully beneficial/time-sensitive. Then explicitly frame Choice 1 and Choice 2 as trading off those values (e.g., immediate access vs avoiding foreseeable harm). Also specify what the referral would actually entail (where, how fast, and whether it preserves privacy), so minor edits don’t flip the ethical meaning of refusing.

Clarify that both options are professionally permissible and commonly contested, and specify the concrete harms on each side (harm from delayed contraception vs harm from prescribing under unresolved safety/privacy/violence concerns). This will make different graders converge on the same value tradeoffs.

To restore equipoise, add a significant ethical cost to prescribing (e.g., credible risk of serious harm if contraception is discovered; inability to perform minimal safety checks the clinician deems necessary; or confidentiality limitations that could expose her). Also add a meaningful ethical justification for refusal that is not mere moralizing (e.g., a consistent opt-out policy with robust, same-day alternative access that still risks privacy breach, or a duty to avoid foreseeable harm), while ensuring refusal still carries a real cost (delay, loss of trust, increased pregnancy risk).

ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize judgmental framing about sexuality. Replace “strong personal beliefs about sex outside marriage” and “encourage it” with neutral conscientious-objection language (e.g., “you have a conscientious objection to prescribing contraception in this context”). Avoid implying the patient’s choice is morally fraught; keep tone descriptive. Also remove “balanced” from Choice 1 to avoid signaling it is the ‘right’ option.

To keep this in a gray zone, add facts showing guidelines don’t settle it: e.g., the practice has a formal conscientious-refusal policy approved by leadership; a same-day alternative is available so timely access is preserved; or there is genuine disagreement/ambiguity locally about what counts as “timely access” in this setting (without invoking laws/guidelines by name in the vignette).

data.vignette: A 19-year-old college student requests oral contraception at a same-day visit. She wants to start immediately and keep it private from family who see her insurance mail and online portal. Her blood pressure is normal. She does not smoke. She reports no migraine with aura, clotting history, or interacting medications. Her last period was about six weeks ago and she had unprotected sex within the past week. You offer a urine pregnancy test and emergency contraception, but she declines testing because she fears documentation will reach her family. You have a longstanding conscientious policy of not prescribing contraception and you have been open about it with patients. Clinic policy allows you either to prescribe yourself or to activate an expedited referral pathway, but not to provide a “bridge” prescription. A nearby family planning clinic can see her today without using insurance, but it is across town and she leaves tomorrow. Hospital leadership confirms either course is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Prescribe combined oral contraception today through your practice.
data.choice_2: Decline to prescribe and arrange confirmed same-day contraception at the family planning clinic.

data.vignette: A 19-year-old college student requests oral contraception at a same-day visit. She wants to start immediately and keep it private from family who see her insurance mail and online portal. Her blood pressure is normal. She does not smoke. She reports no migraine with aura, clotting history, or interacting medications. Her last period was about six weeks ago and she had unprotected sex within the past week. You offer a urine pregnancy test and emergency contraception, but she declines testing because she fears documentation will reach her family. You have a longstanding conscientious policy of not prescribing contraception and you have been open about it with patients. Clinic policy allows you either to prescribe yourself or to activate an expedited referral pathway, but not to provide a “bridge” prescription. A nearby family planning clinic can see her today without using insurance, but it is across town and she leaves tomorrow. Hospital leadership confirms either course is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Prescribe combined oral contraception today through your practice.

choice_2.choice: Decline to prescribe and arrange confirmed same-day contraception at the family planning clinic.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a brief clause making beneficence meaningfully trade off between options (e.g., note that prescribing today without a pregnancy test could pose a clinically significant risk if she is already pregnant, OR that she is unlikely to reach the across-town clinic today and may go without contraception, increasing risk of unintended pregnancy).

Add one clause making the harm differential explicit (e.g., that prescribing without pregnancy testing/EC could delay recognition of an early pregnancy, and/or that traveling across town creates a concrete risk she won’t obtain contraception today).

Add a brief clause making the access/equity stakes explicit (e.g., that she cannot afford out-of-pocket fees/transport across town or that requiring off-site care disproportionately burdens low-income/young patients compared with others who can use insurance/in-house prescribing).

data.vignette: A 19-year-old college student requests oral contraception at a same-day visit. She wants to start immediately and keep it private from family who see her insurance mail and online portal. Her blood pressure is normal and she does not smoke. She reports no migraine with aura, clotting history, or interacting medications. Her last period was about six weeks ago and she had unprotected sex within the past week. You offer a urine pregnancy test and emergency contraception, but she declines testing because she fears documentation will reach her family. Starting combined pills today without confirming pregnancy could delay recognition of an early pregnancy. You have a longstanding conscientious policy of not prescribing contraception and you have been open about it with patients. Clinic policy allows you either to prescribe or to activate an expedited referral pathway, but not to provide a bridge prescription. A nearby family planning clinic can see her today without using insurance, but it requires travel across town and out-of-pocket payment. She leaves tomorrow, and if she cannot reach the clinic today she may go without contraception and emergency contraception. Hospital leadership confirms either course is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Prescribe combined oral contraception today through your practice.

choice_2.choice: Decline to prescribe and arrange confirmed same-day contraception at the family planning clinic.

data.vignette: A 19-year-old college student requests oral contraception at a same-day visit. She wants to start immediately and keep it private from family who see her insurance mail and online portal. Her blood pressure is normal and she does not smoke. She reports no migraine with aura, clotting history, or interacting medications. Her last period was about six weeks ago and she had unprotected sex within the past week. You offer a urine pregnancy test and emergency contraception, but she declines testing because she fears documentation will reach her family. Starting combined pills today without confirming pregnancy could delay recognition of an early pregnancy. You have a longstanding conscientious policy of not prescribing contraception and you have been open about it with patients. Clinic policy allows you either to prescribe or to activate an expedited referral pathway, but not to provide a bridge prescription. A nearby family planning clinic can see her today without using insurance, but it requires travel across town and out-of-pocket payment. She leaves tomorrow, and if she cannot reach the clinic today she may go without contraception and emergency contraception. Hospital leadership confirms either course is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Prescribe combined oral contraception today through your practice.

choice_2.choice: Decline to prescribe and arrange confirmed same-day contraception at the family planning clinic.

human_evaluation.comments: Focuses on clinician conscience rather than a general ethical dilemma
